instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board has no signs of liquid damage. Came in with dead battery and no power. When I plug in adapter I get .4## Volts on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>. Also QB400 gets very hot and after about 30 seconds the charger cuts off. 
I only have the center portion of a donor for this board as I could not find the right side on ALI. I did however order FDPC4044's from mouser and new ISL's as well in hopes that those would be the issue. After replacing QB400 I still get basically nothing on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_GH</SIGNAL> and QB400 is scorching hot.
I have zero experience with this board and to be honest am a bit intimidated, LOL. Here is what I get on he power meter. ------------> [url]https://photos.app.goo.gl/fmqazwSWFTkddYmk9[/url]

Any help is appreciated. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post resistance to ground on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000.

Don't wait again 30s when you already detect overhrating.
In fact, never power up a board before check for shorts...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and DC in? Seems like you have a short causing the fet to get hot possibly a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
12.89k on pin  F7000
.428 Diode


.7 Ohm on pin 1/2 of <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok so DC in is shorted to ground. Inject voltage on that line and see what heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: OK. Thats a 20 V line. What voltage do you think I should start at? Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Don't think to start with 20V.
Always start with low voltage, no matters nominal voltage of the rail.
If you start with 1V, increase voltage maintaining ampers bellow current limit of the bench power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah I'd say start low around 3-4 volts then work your way up. For me, the DC in shorts usually are found at 5 volts so 20 is probably not necessary.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
trying to inject 3.5V on DCIN line. Here are 2 pics. One is with PSU set for voltage injection at 3.5 and the other is while attempting injection. Amperage goes up to 3.9 and board will only take .7 V.

[url]https://photos.app.goo.gl/FwDpj7zjCVdMZLRB7[/url]

I did not force by raising the amps/voltage once I saw that the board wasn't taking it.

Is this a secondary short? What should I do?

Thanks for the help. Have a good one!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Set current limit to max for becnh power supply.
Then start injecting from 1V and go up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok, thank you. Will post back in AM. Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
After injecting voltage I found <CAPACITOR>C7029</CAPACITOR> to be sizzling at 3.5 V. Replaced the cap and all is great!

Thanks a lot [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] & [USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] for all your help. I appreciate your guidance. 

Have a great one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPDC_IN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Good job! Glad we could help
